This is the second guiding
principle for optimizing
energy performance in existing buildings.

The process of establishing
a base line of energy

performance is the starting
point for benchmarking.

Once a building produces
information about how energy

is consumed on site, the
facility team can use this

information to prioritize
improvement projects.

The energy efficiency of a
building can be calculated

using a metric called
Energy Use Intensity,

which is expressed in
kilowatts per square meter.

This concept is used to
measure how efficiently energy

is being used within a building
and allows for comparison

to other buildings of
similar size and operation.
Benchmarking typically aims to improve
the energy use intensity of a building.

There are two common software
tools that can be used to

facilitate the benchmarking
process in the federal sector.

Energy Star Portfolio
Manager and RETScreen Expert

are the leading tool for
tracking and comparing
building energy use over time.

Benchmarking best practices
state that facility managers

should set energy performance
benchmarks annually,
preferably using Portfolio Manager
or RETScreen to compare the actual

performance against the
established benchmark.

This involves regularly
monitoring building
energy performance against historical
performance and peer buildings.

The Government of Canada
is committed to ensuring

accountability for the
government's environmental

performance and will adhere
to this commitment using

the principles of
transparency and open data.

Facilities can demonstrate
proper implementation
using documentation from Energy Star
Portfolio Manager or RETScreen.

Property types that are not
eligible for an Energy Star

score can still generate
reports showing benchmarking

properties and trends
of energy use over time.

Facilities that choose not
to use Portfolio Manager

can set benchmarks and compare
their energy performance
using other means such as utility
billing data, or internal energy reports.

Energy Star Portfolio
Manager is a free, interactive

energy management tool
that allows users to track,

assess, and benchmark
energy and water consumption

for all facility types across
entire building portfolios.

Portfolio Manager has a
standardized metric for comparing

whole building energy
performance to similar
buildings of specific rateable types.
Another tool that can be used for
benchmarking purposes is RETScreen Expert.

Developed by the Government
of Canada, RETScreen Expert

is a software for energy
efficiency and renewable
energy project feasibility analysis,
as well as ongoing energy analysis.

This tool has many functions
and can be used to perform

portfolio wide analysis, collect
information on a facility,

perform benchmarking analysis,
track energy and greenhouse

gas emissions, and for
general performance analysis.

This tool is used widely
throughout government and industry.

Some of the key users include
3M, CRH Canada,

Oxford Properties, Canadian Tire,
The Coalition of Ontario Universities,
National Defense, Public Services and Procurement Canada
and Natural Resources Canada.
